awd_titl_txt: A Systems Analysis of Plant Growth Promotion by the Rhizosphere Microbiome
awd_abstract_narration:
Soil microbial communities represent a largely untapped source for yield improvement in crops. In comparison to plants grown without microbes in the soil, yields can be twice as great when plants are grown with their full complement of soil microbes. Microbes may improve plant growth by making soil nitrogen more available to plants. From the point of view of plant growth and eventual yield, nitrogen is important as it is a critical component of one enzyme, Rubisco, which takes carbon dioxide from the air and converts it to sugars for growth through the process of photosynthesis. To identify how microbes improve plant growth, the current research examines 1. how microbes modify soil chemistry, 2. what plant genes are selectively turned on in response to the presence of microbes, 3. how plant processes like photosynthesis respond to microbes, and 4. what the identity and functions are of the soil microbes. Connecting results from these four sets of data will reveal what it is that promotes plant growth, from the soil to the whole-plant level. This research also includes ways to predict plant growth and yield in response to soil microbes when different amounts of nitrogen are added to the soil, which should enable reduced use of fertilizers. The plant being studied is Brassica rapa, which is grown around the world as root (turnip), leaf (cabbage, pak choi), and oilseed (canola) crops; because of the diverse uses of this crop, results from this species are expected to apply to a wide range of other crops. Soil microbes are an important part of the ecosystem, and connect plants to the physical environment. While much is known about the plants in natural and agricultural settings, less is known about the distributions, types, and functions of beneficial soil microbes, and how they help crops cope with poor growing conditions such as drought or lack of nitrogen. The current research fills these knowledge gaps, and will provide recommendations on how to manage soils for beneficial microbes. Broader impacts to this work include development of guided tours within the Williams Conservatory, Geology Museum, and Berry Center for Biodiversity at the University of Wyoming as well as teaching modules related to the study of evolution and crop domestication. 

Soil microorganisms serve a range of ecosystem services that promote plant growth under stressful abiotic conditions, including nitrogen limitation. Yet, soil microbial communities represent a largely untapped source for yield improvement in crop species. Analyzing plant transcriptomic and physiological responses to taxonomically and functionally diverse soil microbiomes will provide insights as to the mechanisms by which microbes enhance plant growth. Further, Bayesian systems modeling of plant transcriptomic, hydraulic, and gas-exchange responses to the soil microbial environment can provide a predictive understanding of plant growth promotion by microbes under variable nitrogen amendments. When grown with an intact vs. reduced soil microbiome, crops of Brassica rapa upregulate gas-exchange and increase biomass accumulation up to two-fold, suggesting one physiological link between plant transcriptomic responses to soil microbes and eventual plant biomass accumulation. Because B. rapa is domesticated as root, leaf, and oilseed crops, mechanisms of growth promotion characterized in this species could translate to a range of other crops. Further, the microbiome associated with the rhizosphere of B. rapa is highly differentiated from that of bulk soils more distant from the roots, suggesting the species is an effective model for studying the assembly dynamics, identity, and function of beneficial plant-associated soil microbes. Using next-generation amplicon and metagenome sequencing of rhizosphere DNA in combination with plant genomic, transcriptomic, and physiological experiments, the research will characterize mechanisms of plant growth promotion by soil microbes and test predictive systems models. The research addresses the PGRP 2014 focal areas: to develop a genome-level link between genes and physiological functions in crop plants and to develop a genome to systems-level understanding of plant-environmental interactions, especially with respect to abiotic stress. Broader impacts to this work include development of guided tours and teaching modules related to crop domestication and improvement as well as development of management practices for beneficial microbes. Information on this project can be accessed at www.RhizoBiomics.org.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching aim of the research was to characterize genomic mechanisms by which the rhizosphere (rootzone) microbes leads to plant growth promotion, and to develop both process models that predict plant growth promotion by microbes in low input systems as well as recommendations for soil microbial management.

Microbial communities contribute to diverse ecosystem processes in natural and agricultural settings, and affect both plant access to limiting soil nutrients and efficiency in nutrient uptake. As a consequence, microbial associates influence many measures of plant performance, including stress tolerance, biomass accumulation, and ultimately yield.

While the beneficial effects of microbial communities on plant performance have been established in many species, robust characterization of the diversity and abundance of rhizosphere microbes has only recently become tractable through next-generation sequencing technologies. Different plant species form associations with unique microbial communities. Yet, comparatively little is known about microbiome differentiation among plant genotypes within a species or about assembly dynamics of beneficial bacterial communities that may influence plant growth. Further, outside of plant species with mycorrhizal or legume-rhizobium associations, it remains largely unknown how the rhizosphere microbiome affects plant transcriptomic and physiological traits to promote growth and yield in low input settings. Filling this knowledge gap could dramatically increase plant yield without increasing nutrient loadings.

Major Outcomes of the research include the following:

  1. Identification of microbes that promote plant growth. In a series of inter-related growth experiments, we inoculated plants with complex soil microbial communities, enabling the development of a rhizosphere microbiome in otherwise sterile soil.  Using Bayesian modeling, we identified a number of individual microbial taxa that acted either early or late in the life history of the host plant, Brassica rapa, to improve plant growth (Fig. 1, Klasek et al. 2022).  We also re-constructed meta-genome assembled genomes, to place microbial functional genes that potentially influence plant growth in a genomic context (Klasek et al. in prep).
  2. Mechanistic targets-how microbes affect plant performance. We identified plant transcriptomic and metabolomic targets of rhizosphere microbes, that is, how at the molecular level microbial associations may lead to improved growth in Brassica rapa (Fig. 2, Brock et al. in review).  One notable pattern is that microbial association appears to affect the expression of genes that may alleviate plant stress and contribute to improved N status.
  3. Adaptive modulation of the rhizosphere microbiome by host plants. The research provided evidence that plants may modulate the rhizosphere microbiome to their advantage. Namely, the host plant circadian clock timing affects the establishment of the rhizosphere microbiome, and those microbiomes that derive from host plant genotypes with wild-type clock function improve germination timing and growth relative to microbiomes derived from host plant genotypes with an experimentally altered clock cycle (Hubbard et al. 2018). A similar, complex plant-microbe feedback cycle was also identified for plant secondary compounds, glucosinolates (GLS) (Hubbard et al. 2022, DeWolf et al. 2023). Related to GLS, we developed a novel procedure for sampling rhizosphere exudates (chemicals exuded by the plants into the rootzone), and identified that GLS indeed appear in rhizosphere samples consistent with a potential role of native GLS in shaping the microbiome (Fig. 3).
  4. Biophysical process models to predict plant growth responses to microbes. At its core, the process model applied here is a model of photosynthesis that predicts plant growth.  During the course of this project, modules were added to account for root hydraulics (Mackay et al. 2020) and leaf carbon pools (Wang et al. 2019) as well as the potential growth effects of microbes (Fig 4, Hitchcock et al. in prep). We used the revised rTREES model to test a refined set of hypotheses about microbial growth promotion, specifically using TREES with Bayesian analyses to test whether microbes provide a nutrient for growth production or if there is an alternative causal link. The efficiency of our new modeling package has facilitated this more sophisticated enquiry. The role of spatial variations in micrometeorological inputs, especially temperature on plant growth and microbial processes is now a major piece of the story, as we are finding high probability of a microbe-growth promotion link when spatial variability of temperature is considered, but low probability with spatially uniform temperature. Both nutrient and non-nutrient pathways are potentially underlying mechanisms by which microbes could improve plant growth (Fig. 4).
  5. Broader Impacts: Management of beneficial microbes. Ecological priority effects could be used to promote beneficial microbial communities, that is, the early arrival of some microbial taxa to the growth media and plant host influences the establishment and succession of other microbes (Fig. 5). Agronomists may be able to manage the assembly of desirable, plant-growth promoting communities by drawing on priority effects. A further Broader Impact is that our process models are being applied to additional crops of economic significance, including cotton and maize.
